sessions.title: Finally Solving the Expression Problem
sessions.description: UIKit let's us describe view hierarchies by putting together a bunch of UIView and UIView subclasses. We can even create our own views by subclassing UIView ourselves without even reaching into UIKit! But we can't reuse this view description on AppKit or for serialization. Imagine for a moment, we had EnumKit, it's like UIKit, but the views are provided as cases of an enum. Now we can reuse the view description, but we can no longer create our own views without reaching into EnumKit (or forking the library).The 'Final Tagless' approach gives us the best of both worlds taking advantage of Swiftâ€™s powerful Self type inside protocols.
sessions.description_ja: UIKitã§ã¯ã€ä¸€é€£ã® UIView ã¨ UIView ã®ã‚µãƒ–ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¹ã‚’ã¾ã¨ã‚ã¦ãƒ“ãƒ¥ãƒ¼éšå±¤ã‚’è¨˜è¿°ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚UIViewã‚’ã‚µãƒ–ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¹åŒ–ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã«ã‚ˆã£ã¦è‡ªåˆ†è‡ªèº«ã®ãƒ“ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚’ä½œæˆã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã‚‚ã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚ã—ã‹ã—ã€ã“ã® View Description ã‚’AppKitã‚„ã‚·ãƒªã‚¢ãƒ©ã‚¤ã‚¼ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã«å†åˆ©ç”¨ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã¯ã§ãã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚UIKit ã¨ä¼¼ãŸã‚ˆã†ãªã‚‚ã®ã« EnumKit ãŒã‚ã‚Šã€ View ã¯åˆ—æŒ™å‹ã®ã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã¨ã—ã¦æä¾›ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ã“ã‚Œã§ View Description ã‚’ä½¿ã„ã¾ã‚ã™ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã¾ã™ãŒã€EnumKit ãªã—ã§ (ã‚‚ã—ãã¯ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ–ãƒ©ãƒªã‚’ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã—ãªã„ã¨ï¼‰ãƒ“ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚’ç”Ÿæˆã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚'Final Tagless' ã¯ã€Swift ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒˆã‚³ãƒ«ã®å†…éƒ¨ã«ã‚ã‚‹å¼·åŠ›ãª Self å‹ã‚’ç”¨ã„ã¦ã€åŒæ–¹ã®ä¸–ç•Œã‚’ãƒ™ã‚¹ãƒˆãªçŠ¶æ…‹ã«ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

speakers.name: Brandon Kase
speakers.bio: Brandon Kase brings typed functional programming to weird places. He has shipped production code on Android with Kotlin, iOS with Swift and React Native, and Web with JS/Flow/React. Brandon is currently building a new cryptocurrency at O(1) Labs. He came across functional programming while pursuing a B.S. in Computer Science from Carnegie Mellon University. Brandon is excited that strong static typing and functional programming are becoming mainstream, and believes that techniques once reserved for academia will help industry produce more reliable software.
speakers.bio_ja: Brandon Kase ã¯å‹ä»˜é–¢æ•°ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒŸãƒ³ã‚°ã‚’å¥‡å¦™ãªå ´æ‰€ã«å°å…¥ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ Kotlin ã§ Android ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚’ã€ Swift ã‚„ React Native ã§ iOS ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚’ã€ãã—ã¦ JS/Flow/React ã§ Web ã‚µã‚¤ãƒˆã‚’ä½œã£ã¦ãã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ ä»Šã¯ O(1) Lab ã§æ–°ã—ã„æš—å·é€šè²¨ã‚’ä½œã£ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚å½¼ã¯ã‚«ãƒ¼ãƒã‚®ãƒ¼ãƒ¡ãƒ­ãƒ³å¤§å­¦ã§ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ”ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚¿ã‚µã‚¤ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¹ã®å­¦ä½ã‚’å–ã‚ŠãªãŒã‚‰ã€é–¢æ•°ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒŸãƒ³ã‚°ã‚’å­¦ã‚“ã§ãã¾ã—ãŸã€‚å¼·ã„é™çš„å‹ä»˜ã‘ã‚„é–¢æ•°ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒŸãƒ³ã‚°ãŒä¸»æµã¨ãªã£ã¦ããŸã“ã¨ã«ãƒ¯ã‚¯ãƒ¯ã‚¯ã—ã¦ãŠã‚Šã€ã‹ã¤ã¦å­¦å•ã®ãŸã‚ã«é€²ã‚“ã æŠ€è¡“ãŒã€ã‚ˆã‚Šå“è³ªã®é«˜ã„ã‚½ãƒ•ãƒˆã‚¦ã‚§ã‚¢ã‚’ä½œã‚Šå‡ºã™ã“ã¨ã«å½¹ç«‹ã¤ã¨ä¿¡ã˜ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚è‰¯ã„è¨­è¨ˆã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒŸãƒ³ã‚°è¨€èªã‚„ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ–ãƒ©ãƒªãªã©ã«ãƒãƒã£ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

sessions.title: Swift Peer Lab Barcelona
sessions.description: I want to share my experience of creating a Swift Peer Lab in the city of Barcelona. I will start by explaining the peer lab concept. Then I will share why I believe itâ€™s an easy and rewarding experience and how you can do it in your city. I will also share some numbers and tips from my experience.

speakers.name: Tiago Martinho
speakers.bio: Tiago Martinho is a Developer at ThoughtWorks in Barcelona - he created Swift Peer Labs in Barcelona. He loves to create apps, mainly for iOS (he already built more than 15 projects). Tiago is currently studying Machine Learning. He started iOS development professionally with Swift 1.0 in 2014.

sessions.title: Using Swift to Visualize Algorithms
sessions.description: Visual aids can help make clear how an algorithm functions. In this talk we will examine how UIBezierPath works, by reimplementing the algorithm in an interactive way that we can see. Using Swift playgrounds, we can quickly get feedback about our implementation and use it as a learning tool.

speakers.name: Ben Scheirman
speakers.bio: Ben Scheirman is an independent software developer from Houston, Texas. He is best known for creating NSScreencast, a site that delivers quality training videos on iOS development. Ben has been writing iOS apps since 2009, and has produced more than 300 videos teaching others to do the same. You can find Benâ€™s website at benscheirman.com or follow him on Twitter @subdigital.
speakers.bio_ja: Ben Scheirman ã¯ãƒ’ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ³å‡ºèº«ã®å€‹äººé–‹ç™ºè€…ã§ã™ã€‚iOSé–‹ç™ºã‚’å‹•ç”»ã§å­¦ã¹ã‚‹ NSScreencast ã‚’ä½œã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã§ã‚ˆãçŸ¥ã‚‰ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚Ben ã¯2009å¹´ã‹ã‚‰iOSã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚’ä½œã‚Šå§‹ã‚ã¦ã€300æœ¬ä»¥ä¸Šã®å‹•ç”»ã‚’ä½œæˆã—ã¦ãã¾ã—ãŸã€‚Webã‚µã‚¤ãƒˆ benscheirman.com ã‚„ Twitter @subdigital ã‚’ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯ã—ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚

sessions.title: Codable Routing with Kitura
sessions.description: Swift 4 introduced the Codable interface that, through JSONEncoder and JSONDecoder, makes working with JSON a really pleasurable experience. Encoding and decoding JSON often becomes the most complex part of working with RESTful APIs. Using Codable, Kitura 2.0 offers to take up the responsibility of JSON processing, allowing you to work directly with your own Codable types, in a type-safe manner. Using KituraKit, you may also share type definitions between the iOS app and the server side.
sessions.description_ja: Swift 4ã§ã¯ã€Codable ãŒå°å…¥ã•ã‚Œã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ã“ã‚Œã¯ã€JSONEncoder ã‚„ JSONDecoder ã‚’é€šã—ã¦ã€JSON ã‚’æ‰±ã„ã‚„ã™ãã—ã¦ãã‚Œã‚‹ã‚‚ã®ã§ã™ã€‚ JSONã®ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã‚„ãƒ‡ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ãŒã€RESTful API ã‚’æ‰±ã†éš›ã®ä¸€ç•ªè¤‡é›‘ãªéƒ¨åˆ†ã§ã™ã€‚Codable ã‚’ä½¿ã†ã“ã¨ã§ã€ Kitura 2.0 ã¯ JSON ã®å‡¦ç†ã®è²¬å‹™ã‚’å—ã‘æŒã¡ã€å‹å®‰å…¨ãªæ–¹æ³•ã§ã€ç‹¬è‡ªã® Codable å‹ã§ç›´æ¥å‡¦ç†ã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚KituraKit ã‚’ç”¨ã„ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã§ã€iOS ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã¨ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼ã‚µã‚¤ãƒ‰ã®é–“ã§å‹ã®å®šç¾©ã‚’å…±æœ‰ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã‚‹ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚

speakers.name: Pushkar Kulkarni
speakers.bio: Pushkar Kulkarni is a server-side Swift developer working with IBM. Prior to Swift, he worked on IBM's Java runtime, working on the JIT compiler and the Java standard library. Over the last two years, he has been contributing to open source Swift Foundation, focussed on making URLSession fully functional on Linux. He thinks Swift is the coolest language ever and is excited about the opportunities it offers on the server side.
speakers.bio_ja: Pushkar Kulkarni ã¯ IBM ã®ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼ã‚µã‚¤ãƒ‰ Swift ã®é–‹ç™ºè€…ã§ã™ã€‚Swift ã«é–¢ã‚ã‚‹å‰ã¯ã€IBM ã® Java ã®ãƒ©ãƒ³ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ ã®éƒ¨ç½²ã«ã„ã¦ã€ JIT ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ‘ã‚¤ãƒ©ã‚„ã€ Java ã®æ¨™æº–ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ–ãƒ©ãƒªã‚’é–‹ç™ºã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚éå»äºŒå¹´é–“ã€ã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³ã‚½ãƒ¼ã‚¹ Swift ã® Foundation ã«ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒˆãƒªãƒ“ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒˆã—ã¦ãŠã‚Šã€ç‰¹ã« Linux ã® URLSession é–¢æ•°å‹ã®ä¸–ç•Œã«ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã«æ³¨åŠ›ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚Swift ã¯æœ€ã‚‚ã‚¯ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãªè¨€èªã§ã€ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼ã‚µã‚¤ãƒ‰ã§æä¾›ã•ã‚Œã‚‹ã“ã¨ã«ã‚ãã‚ãã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

sessions.title: Super Resolution with CoreML
sessions.description: The 'super resolution' technique is used for converting low resolution image into high resolution, which reduces the amount of image data that needs to be transfered. In this talk, I'd like to show you the implementation of super resolution with CoreML and Swift, and compare the results with conventional methods.

speakers.name: Kentaro Matsumae
speakers.bio: Kentaro Matsumae is an engineer at DeNA, where he works on the MangaBox iOS app. Previously, he worked on several other apps including niconico. When not coding, he studies machine learning.

sessions.title: Introducing Charles for iOS
sessions.description: Many of the apps we develop access APIs over the internet. Charles Proxy running on macOS lets you capture the HTTP and HTTPS traffic from iOS, so you can debug faults and measure performance. At try! Swift Tokyo, Karlâ€“the creator of Charles Proxyâ€“will unveil a new and more powerful approach: Charles for iOS; enabling you to capture traffic directly on your iOS device.
sessions.description_ja: æˆ‘ã€…ãŒé–‹ç™ºã™ã‚‹ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã®å¤šããŒã€ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒãƒƒãƒˆçµŒç”±ã§APIã«ã‚¢ã‚¯ã‚»ã‚¹ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚macOSä¸Šã§å®Ÿè¡Œã•ã‚Œã‚‹Charles Proxyã¯ã€iOSã‹ã‚‰ã® HTTP ã¨ HTTPS ã®ãƒˆãƒ©ãƒ•ã‚£ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’ã‚­ãƒ£ãƒ—ãƒãƒ£ã§ãã‚‹ãŸã‚ã€éšœå®³ã‚’ãƒ‡ãƒãƒƒã‚°ã—ãŸã‚Šã€ãƒ‘ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚’æ¸¬å®šã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚try!Swift Tokyoã§ã¯ã€Charles Proxy ã®ä½œè€…ã§ã‚ã‚‹ Karl ãŒ Charles for iOS ã¨ã„ã†æ–°ã—ãå¼·åŠ›ãªã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒã‚’ç™ºè¡¨ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ã“ã‚Œã«ã‚ˆã‚Šã€ã‚ãªãŸã®iOSãƒ‡ãƒã‚¤ã‚¹ã§ãƒˆãƒ©ãƒ•ã‚£ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’ç›´æ¥ã‚­ãƒ£ãƒ—ãƒãƒ£ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒå¯èƒ½ã¨ãªã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚

speakers.name: Karl von Randow
speakers.bio: Back in the olden days Karl was co-founder of Camera+, which sold over 12 million copies on the App Store. More recently he created Vee for Videoâ€”an app for quickly shooting, editing and sharing video. He is also the creator of Charles Proxyâ€”a popular desktop app for observing an appâ€™s network trafficâ€”and co-founder of Letterboxdâ€”a social website and app for movie lovers. Karl likes creating things.
speakers.bio_ja: ã‹ã¤ã¦ã€Karl ã¯ App Store ã§1200ä¸‡ä»¥ä¸Šãƒ€ã‚¦ãƒ³ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹ Camera+ ã® Co-Founder ã§ã—ãŸã€‚ æœ€è¿‘ã§ã¯ã€å‹•ç”»ã‚’ç´ æ—©ãã¨ã£ãŸã‚Šã€ç·¨é›†ã—ãŸã‚Šã€å…±æœ‰ã—ãŸã‚Šã™ã‚‹ã€Vee for Video ã‚’ã„ã†ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚’ä½œã‚Šã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ã¾ãŸã€ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã®ãƒãƒƒãƒˆãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ç›£è¦–ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒƒãƒ—ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã¨ã—ã¦äººæ°—ã®ã‚ã‚‹ã€Charles Proxy ã‚‚ä½œã£ã¦ã„ãŸã‚Šã€å‹•ç”»ãŒå¤§å¥½ããªäººã®ãŸã‚ã®ã‚½ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ£ãƒ«ã‚¦ã‚§ãƒ–ã‚µã‚¤ãƒˆã¨ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã§ã‚ã‚‹ã€ Letterboxd ã® Co-Founder ã§ã‚‚ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚ç‰©ã‚’ä½œã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒå¤§å¥½ããªã®ã§ã™ã€‚
speakers.job_title: Creator of Camera+, Charles Proxy, and Vee
speakers.job_title_ja: Creator of Camera+, Charles Proxy, and Vee

sessions.title: Designing Experiences With Augmented Reality
sessions.description: As technology becomes more ubiquitous with the real world, it is inevitable that experiences will go beyond screens and in physical space. Like VR and Voice, Augmented Reality (AR) is one of the emerging technologies experiencing an undiscovered phase, similar to mobile applications just a decade ago.David Hoang shares his experiences designing for AR. This talk will cover the best practices of what makes a great AR experience, how to prototype physically, and share a few concepts using Appleâ€™s ARKit.

speakers.name: David Hoang
speakers.bio:
David Hoang loves Swift, Visual Programming, and infusing the design and engineering process together. In his 15-year career he has worked in B2B at ExactTarget, Brand at HTC, being a founder of a digital studio, Design Director at Black Pixel, and now Head of Product Design at One Medical. 

Heâ€™s worked on three apps featured by Apple and got into programming as a designer with the desire to push ideas to become more tangible. Itâ€™s true that he has a VM of Mac OS 9 running so he can use HyperCard. 

When heâ€™s not working, David likes to collaborate with other designers and engineers, travel, read, and paint. He currently lives in San Francisco, California, but his heart is back in New York City.
speakers.bio_ja:
David Hoang ã¯ã€ Swift ã‚„ãƒ“ã‚¸ãƒ¥ã‚¢ãƒ«ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒŸãƒ³ã‚°ãŒå¤§å¥½ãã§ã€ãƒ‡ã‚¶ã‚¤ãƒ³ã¨ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ãƒªãƒ³ã‚°ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚»ã‚¹ã‚’èåˆã•ã›ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ã“ã®15å¹´ã§ã€ ExactTarget ã® B2Bã€HTC ã®ãƒ–ãƒ©ãƒ³ãƒ‰æ‹…å½“ã€ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ã‚¹ã‚¿ã‚¸ã‚ªã®å‰µè¨­è€…ã€Black Pixel ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¶ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¬ã‚¯ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã‚’çµŒã¦ã€ä»Šã§ã¯ One Medical ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ€ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒ‡ã‚¶ã‚¤ãƒ³ã®ãƒ˜ãƒƒãƒ‰ã¨ã—ã¦åƒã„ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

Appleã«ãƒ•ã‚£ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ£ãƒ¼ã•ã‚ŒãŸ3ã¤ã®ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚’ã¤ãã£ã¦ãŠã‚Šã€ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‡ã‚£ã‚¢ã‚’ã‚ˆã‚Šå…·ç¾åŒ–ã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã«ãƒ‡ã‚¶ã‚¤ãƒŠãƒ¼ã¨ã—ã¦ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒŸãƒ³ã‚°ã‚’ã¯ã˜ã‚ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚HyperCardã‚’ä½¿ãˆã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ã«ã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã«ã€Mac OS 9ãŒå‹•ä½œã™ã‚‹VMã‚’æŒã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã®ã¯æœ¬å½“ã®ã“ã¨ã§ã™ã€‚ä»•äº‹ä»¥å¤–ã§ã¯ã€ä»–ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¶ã‚¤ãƒŠãƒ¼ã‚„ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã¨å”æ¥­ã—ãŸã‚Šã€æ—…è¡Œã‚„èª­æ›¸ã€ãƒšã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒˆã™ã‚‹ã®ãŒå¥½ãã§ã™ã€‚ä»Šã¯ã‚µãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©ãƒ³ã‚·ã‚¹ã‚³ã«ã™ã‚“ã§ã¾ã™ãŒã€æƒ³ã„å‡ºã¯ãƒ‹ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ¨ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã«ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚
speakers.job_title: Head of Product Design at One Medical
speakers.job_title_ja: Head of Product Design at One Medical

sessions.title: Kotlin For Swift Developers
sessions.description: Kotlin is a functional language written on top of the JVM that your Android friends are probably *really* excited about. It's got quite a bit in common with Swift, and learning to read it can help you communicate more easily with your Android team.  You'll get a look at this new language from a Swift perspective - what things are the same, what things are not, and what things each language's partisans can be jealous of in the other.

speakers.name: Ellen Shapiro
speakers.bio: Ellen Shapiro is a native mobile developer who recently moved to the Netherlands. She's been building iOS and Android apps since 2010, and was most recently the lead mobile developer for SpotHero. In addition, Ellen writes and edits iOS and Android tutorials for RayWenderlich.com, and is the lead developer for Hum, a prominent iOS app for songwriting. In her spare time Ellen enjoys playing the guitar, traveling, biking, and hanging out with her girlfriend and their two cats.

sessions.title: Preparing for Swift 5 Ownership
sessions.description: Ownership is a new Swift 5 feature that will appear later this year. Although it is important for ABI stabilization, mastering Ownership can help reduce memory copies and improve program performance. In this session, Toru Kuriyama will outline Ownership based on the contents of the Ownership Manifesto released last year.

speakers.name: Toru Kuriyama
speakers.bio: Toru Kuriyama is an iOS application engineer at Sansan Inc, which handles business card management service, and develops 'Sansan' iOS app for corporations.

sessions.title: Digital Signal Processing with Swift
sessions.description: A deep dive into the field of digital signal processing and how Appleâ€™s Accelerate framework makes use of Fast Fourier Transforms for detecting audio frequencies. Join me and see how we can use a powerful language like Swift to break down audio sampling rates with an interactive live demo.

speakers.name: Daisy Ramos
speakers.bio: Daisy is an avid iOS developer and lover of all that is tech. Most recently working on the iOS team at Citi FinTech building data-driven solutions and new features for their consumer banking app. She also actively consults for early stage companies looking to build the next big thing. Daisy holds a B.S in Computer Science from Queens College in NYC, the same college where the try! Swift NYC meetup originated. She now organizes the meetup and hosts a wide variety of technical Swift talks. She can be found on twitter as @daisyr317.
speakers.bio_ja: Daisy ã¯ç†±å¿ƒãªiOSã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã§æŠ€è¡“ãŒå¤§å¥½ãã§ã™ã€‚æœ€è¿‘ã¯ Citi FinTech ã§ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ‰ãƒªãƒ–ãƒ³ãªã‚½ãƒªãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’æ§‹ç¯‰ã—ãŸã‚Šã€è‡ªç¤¾é¡§å®¢å‘ã‘ã®éŠ€è¡Œã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã¸ã®æ–°æ©Ÿèƒ½ã‚’è¿½åŠ ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ã¾ãŸã€å°†æ¥å¤§ããªã“ã¨ã‚’æˆã—é‚ã’ã‚ˆã†ã¨ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã‚¢ãƒ¼ãƒªãƒ¼ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¸ã®ä¼šç¤¾ã¸ã®ã‚³ãƒ³ã‚µãƒ«ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ³ã‚°ã«ã‚‚ç©æ¥µçš„ã§ã™ã€‚try! Swift NYC meetup ã®æ‰€ç¸ã®åœ°ã§ã‚‚ã‚ã‚‹ã€ãƒ‹ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ¨ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã® Queens College ã§ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ”ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚¿ã‚µã‚¤ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¹ã®å­¦å£«ã‚’å–ã‚Šã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ä»Šã¯å¤šç¨®å¤šæ§˜ãª Swift ã®æŠ€è¡“çš„ãªãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãŒæŠ«éœ²ã•ã‚Œã‚‹ãƒŸãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚¢ãƒƒãƒ—ã‚’ä¸»å®°ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚Twitterã¯ @daisyr317 ã§ã™ã€‚

sessions.title: The Type-Safe World of Codable
sessions.description: You might be surprised to learn that Codable can be used for various situation beyond just mapping API responses, including making source code more type safe. In this talk, Tatsuya Tanaka will introduce you to this more powerful way of using Codable.

speakers.name: Tatsuya Tanaka
speakers.bio: Tatsuya Tanaka is an engineer at Yahoo! JAPAN, where he mainly develops transit iOS apps. When not coding, he shares iOS tips at meetups or on his blog. You can find him at Hackathons.

sessions.title: Creating conversational interfaces in iOS/Swift
sessions.description: We'll explore the latest technologies for creating conversational interfaces in your app. We'll explore speech recognition, both with Apple's APIs and other solutions such as Amazon Lex. We'll also explore different strategies for voice playback. Lastly, we'll talk about best design practices when building conversational interfaces in your apps.

speakers.name: Wendy Lu
speakers.bio: Wendy is an iOS engineer and has been working at Pinterest for the last 5 years. She is currently engineering manager of the Ad Formats team with a focus on mobile. Previously, she led the launch of their commerce product on mobile and has also touched everything from the data layer to the UI frameworks. She has given talks at several iOS conferences and moderates a mobile development panel at Grace Hopper. In a past life she competed on the US Synchronised Swimming National Team.

sessions.title: UIImageView vs Metal
sessions.description: Metal is an API that provides access to the GPU. Apple announced it's 10x times faster than OpenGL. In this session, I'll explain the basics of Metal, then compare the performance of graphics rendering with UIImageView. Even if you don't use the API directly, your app is implicitly benefitting from Metal. This comparison to a familiar class will lead you to be conscious of the GPU layer that we usually miss.

speakers.name: Shuichi Tsutsumi
speakers.bio: Shuichi has been a freelance iOS developer in Tokyo, and works for Fyusion Inc. in San Francisco since 2016. Co-authored â€œiOS x BLE Core Bluetooth Programmingâ€ (2015) and authored â€œiOS Programming - Advanced 100 Recipesâ€ (2013). He is the creator of some popular OSS repositories such as iOS Sampler series.

sessions.title: Best Docker Container in Swift
sessions.description: Several years have passed since Swift was released as open source and Linux became supported. The adoption of server side Swift has increased. Meanwhile, Swift is constantly being updated, and the cost of supporting different Swift versions on multiple machines is getting higher. By using Docker, this cost can be reduced by preparing a virtual environment container with a fixed Swift version, so we can develop without relying on version. Also, since Docker does not perform full virtualization, disk usage is small, and virtual environment initialization and startup are fast. In this talk, I'll explore the best Docker container for Swift.

speakers.name: Takeshi Ihara
speakers.bio: Takeshi Ihara is an iOS engineer of English learning services at Recruit Marketing Partners. He uses server side Swift in his personal apps. When not coding, you can find him bouldering or playing games.
speakers.job_title: iOS Engineer at Recruit Marketing Partners
speakers.job_title_ja: iOS Engineer at Recruit Marketing Partners

sessions.title: The Type Erasure Advantage
sessions.description: Type erasure, which was presented at try! Swift Tokyo 2016, is now known by many Swift developers. This talk will focus on the type and performance advantages of adopting type erasure. We will also cover the AnySequence implementation in stdlib to explore an efficient and powerful type erasure implementation.

speakers.name: Nobuo Saito
speakers.bio: Nobuo Saito is an engineer at Mercari. He likes Swift, games and sleeping, so he has problems with time allocation. He recently bought MHW, so the time required for gaming has doubled. It is serious.
speakers.bio_ja: æ ªå¼ä¼šç¤¾ãƒ¡ãƒ«ã‚«ãƒªæ‰€å±ã® iOS ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã§ã™ã€‚ Swift ã¨ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ ã¨ç¡çœ ãŒå¥½ãã§ã€æ™‚é–“é…åˆ†ã«æ‚©ã‚“ã§ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚æœ€è¿‘ MHW ã‚’è²·ã£ã¦ã—ã¾ã„ã€ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ ã«å¿…è¦ãªæ™‚é–“ãŒ2å€ã«ãªã£ã¦ã—ã¾ã„ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚å¤§å¤‰ã§ã™ã€‚

sessions.title: Investing time into developer tools and experience
sessions.description: How to look for ideas to improve developer tooling and experience. Weâ€™ll look at examples of common pain points in daily development and techniques that can be used to improve them, either through creating new developer tools or adjusting the development process. If the 10x developer exists, it's the person that decides to work on things that make the lives of the other 10 developers better.

speakers.name: Krzysztof ZabÅ‚ocki
speakers.bio: Krzysztof is the Lead iOS developer at The New York Times, known for creating Sourcery, Objective-C Playgrounds, and Appleâ€™s Essential Apps like Foldify and 3D Game Engines. Passionate about writing quality code and helping other do the same. He blogs on merowing.info and open sources tools/libraries on github.com/krzysztofzablocki.
